slides.title: jQuery Mobile
bullets: Focused on helping you build a consistant user interface

slides.title: Philosophy
bullets: Uses data- attributes on html elements to signify a specific user interface feature
Adds and/or modifies the elements you have in your web page
Get a descent user interface with minimal effort
Harder to style exactly like you want
May need to debug the css to find out how to change styles
Might be a bit heavy for older phones

slides.title: The page
bullets: jQuery has added its own concept of a "page"
One single html file can contain many pages
Will use Ajax even when loading a different html file into the current page
Define every page containing element as having the data-role "page"
A page can then contain header, content and footer

slides.title: Multiple pages and links between them
bullets: jQuery will handle switching between pages
Can use animation for page switches
Uses Ajax as default for internal links to other files too
Create link with hash and id
Turn off jQuery handling with rel

slides.title: Themes
bullets: jQuery Mobile introduces themes for changing the style of all elements
Just another css file, but by defining the class names for the styles, other parties can also create themes for your content
Specify the data-theme attribute for the page or an individual element
A few built-in themes available as a, b, c, d, e

slides.title: Events
bullets: More complicated handling of the document load event
Place your own JavaScript code/file between jQuery and JQuery Mobile

slides.title: Swipe events
bullets: jQuery Mobile supports detecting left and right swipes

slides.title: Server side storage
bullets: Most apps need to store data on the server
Access the same information from multiple locations (browsers)
Nature of the web/JavaScript means you can't hide server access
Always need to login in order to save and protect data on the server side

slides.title: Build your own API
bullets: How to handle server side storage and client side user interface
Intermix html/JavaScript with server side script
Keep html/JavaScript separate from server side script

slides.title: Integrating with other services
bullets: Unique url (like only having a password)

slides.title: OAuth
bullets: For giving a site access to your data, without ever knowing your password
Requires some cryptographic signing code (need library)
Is considered sequre even over http (no SSL)
Simpler, just building urls, no cryptography needed
Need to register your site/app at Twitter/Facebook/Google
You'll get a public app id and a secret token
